abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Sector
            Stability Credit (FSSC) Project for Nepal were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: by quickly
            responding to the client's request for assistance, the
            Bank continues to be regarded as a valued partner. It was
            important to maintain sufficient flexibility to adapt and
            respond to client needs and economic realities in the
            country. Bank assistance and support in simply initiating
            difficult reform actions through the operation facilitated
            the clients ability and momentum to continue the full and
            complete implementation of reform actions, even after the
            operation closed, albeit at a slower pace. The slowdown in
            implementation of some key policy actions after the release
            of the FSSC funds implies that the scope of the reforms was
            ambitious in the context of Nepal's political
            circumstances. The implications of the short time frame for
            the closure of the FSSC oblige the need for a more realistic
            timeframe in the follow-on programmatic operations and
            secondly, for a more narrowly defined project development
            objective (PDO) and set of outcome indicators for the
            planned programmatic operations. Cooperation among
            international agencies (that is, Department for
            International Development (DFID), International Monetary
            Fund (IMF), and Asian Development Bank (ADB)) proved
            essential, since extensive technical assistance has been
            provided and coordinated with this operation and aligned
            with the countrys priorities and strategic goals. The
            broadening of the DFID technical assistance program over the
            coming years should also allow expansion of the scope of
            forthcoming development policy credit (DPC) operations and
            Bank-DFID cooperation is continuing as the preparation of
            additional DPCs moves forward.
